PIONEER SURVEY: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our province.

Name: Mr. William Johnson
Address: 123 Main Street, Saskatoon
Birthplace: North England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? (City) Regina, 10 miles east of the townsite.
Where had you been living before that? (City) Toronto, Ontario.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 5
How far was it to your nearest store? 1 mile
How often could a visit be made to the store? once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, tea, sugar, lard, dried apples, raisins, oatmeal, beans, etc.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? (Brand) Red Star
In what quantities did you buy it? (Quantity) 50 pounds
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50
How much did you use graham flour? (Amount) 10 pounds
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? (Distance) 10 miles
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? (Price) $0.40
What other grain products did you use? (Products) Cornmeal, whole wheat, parina
Other? (Other) None
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? (Method) On a hand grinder

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1918-19
Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Up until what time 1919 we had always had Christmas dinner with the friends my husband people when we started having it at our home, a farm 2 miles east of Floydminster where we had moved to enable our children to attend school at Floydminster our farm was then in the Floydminster school district in which we paid taxes.
Our first Christmas dinner in our own house included the grandparents, uncles & aunts & our neighbors the Garrets who had lately come out from England.
We had grown with all the trimmings, 3 or 4 eggs plum pudding, mince pie, fruit, nuts & candy.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Down to Rolled Oats. Spring of 1906. New made trips to Fort Pitt to bring freight of groceries. On arriving found the Steam floating from Edmonton sank on sandbar so had not arrived.
So all people were on last rations.
Men came back empty, and glad to get porridge without trimmings. About the lowest state of provisions.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Bought as much by sack and in quantities as possible. Flour 98 lb, sugar 20 lb, oatmeal 25 lb, tea, 3 lb, flour, etc., bacon large side. Beef by force at head quarters. More time was used in cooking so there were no prepared foods or purchased foods. Bread, jam, and preserves were prepared at home. Butter made from cream etc.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

When railway came more packaged food available but always used as much home grown as possible owing to saving costs. Fruit & perishable regs. It came when the C.N.R. had refrigerator cars.
